steps.description: The paper establishes that PARK7/DJ-1 mutations are linked to autosomal-recessive early-onset PD. The study demonstrates that these mutations disrupt TTRAP interaction and trigger apoptosis via JNK/p38-MAPK pathways, directly linking them to disease mechanisms.
Yeast two-hybrid screening was used to assess protein interactions (TRAF/TTRAP) relevant to PD pathogenesis. This assay aligns with the disease mechanism of disrupted cellular protection.

Wild-type DJ-1 and mutant variants (M26I/L166P) were compared. The study explicitly contrasts mutant and wild-type binding, fulfilling the requirement for normal/abnormal controls. However, the text does not mention statistical replicates (e.g., n=3).
No additional pathogenic/benign variant controls were used in the assay. The analysis focused solely on the tested mutants and wild-type.

The paper reports qualitative findings (e.g., 'bind more strongly than wild-type') but lacks statistical tests, p-values, or OddsPath calculations. Only two variants (M26I/L166P) were tested, with wild-type as a control.

final_strength.description: The variant disrupts TTRAP interaction and triggers apoptosis, aligning with pathogenic mechanisms. However, limited statistical rigor and controls reduce strength to 'supporting'.

steps.description: As with M26I, the study confirms that L166P mutations impair TTRAP interaction and induce apoptosis, directly contributing to PD pathogenesis.
The yeast two-hybrid assay remains relevant for assessing TTRAP interaction and its role in apoptosis, consistent with the disease mechanism.
Wild-type DJ-1 and mutant variants (L166P) were compared, fulfilling the normal/abnormal control requirement. Replicates are not explicitly mentioned.
No additional pathogenic/benign variant controls were used in the assay. The analysis focused solely on the tested mutants and wild-type.
The study lacks statistical tests, p-values, or OddsPath calculations. Only two variants (L166P) were tested, with wild-type as a control.

final_strength.description: The variant disrupts TTRAP interaction and triggers apoptosis, aligning with pathogenic mechanisms. However, limited statistical rigor and controls reduce strength to 'supporting'.
